Engineers to think about when it might be time to consider a cloud development environment like coda.com so as a
platform engineer developers might constantly be opening like it tickets that their computer isn't working
properly they might constantly want to update dependencies but that's a big mess you constantly have to email people
across your team to say hey Adam could we update from java 17 to Java 18 those are the kinds of problems that people

you try to reduce the complexity of your products instead of Simply you know leveraging better Hardware we believe
that the future is leveraging the cloud for a lot of these things you can get more powerful instances in gcp or AWS
that can make the build times faster instantly you can let one developer create a standardized environment and
then distribute it to a th so that when you're updating from java 17 to 18 it's just a simple pull request you can

get immediate data transfers and it's not slow many of our customers which is a crazy thing to say but they use
absolutely massive monor repos and they get clones that go from like 10 minutes or 20 minutes or an hour to Simply like
a minute or 30 seconds it's just a lot simpler when all of your engineers are standardized on one centralized piece of
infrastructure and then one person can can impact the lives of hundreds of Engineers and with that we don't believe
that everything belongs in the cloud we think that some workloads are really amazing for it and some are absolutely

Services is writing documentation a lot of the time that ends up just being like

defining all the inputs outputs um defining models doing a load of very complex stuff that we'll talk about
later but it provides a really nice way of being able to have a consistent

a go command line tool and library for generating go code from your open API so
it was started I think it was fiveish Years Ago by my co-maintainer Marin who was working at a company called Deep map
which been acquired by Nvidia and one of the things he was looking at was at the time open API
three was fairly recently out previously there was a thing called Swagger which
has been retroactively renamed open API 2.0 and so there were load of tools that
were built around Swagger such as Swagger Coen and the open API 3 and
above ecosystem wasn't really very modern oh not very modern wasn't really
um there weren't a lot of good tools out there and looking at the state of open
API generator which was one of the other ones it didn't really provide very idiomatic go code so the product itself was built
with Java and so one of the problems was if you wanted to generate code you had to install Java as well which was fine
like on local machines but in CI one of the great things about go is it's lightweight you just need to install the
go tool chain and you're ready to go if you're then also installing Java and various other things it just adds on um
the burd of what you need to run your builds so Maron was looking at this uh looking at the non-idiomatic Go code
that there was I was like you know what I can do that as many Engineers think you know what I could do better than
that in a weekend most most preferably exactly um and so OPI genen was born and
it provided a way of generating more idiomatic go code from your open API spec so provided you have a fully
written open API spec it would then generate code so it would give you your client boiler plate it would give you
any service side boiler plate for various number of routs and servers and it was also generate all your models so
you don't have to do a load of pretty boring work that can be easily automated by a machine it generates all that code

you don't touch the generated code at all so what we do is we generate a single file of go code but we provide a
number of interfaces for consumers to implement so for instance if you're generating a server based on say the new
enhance routing in go1 122 you get generated a load of boiler plate for
this method on this interface is this HTTP method and this route and then you
simply Implement a subset of the code um which gets wrapped by the boiler plate
so it will do things like pull out required HTTP headers it will pause your query string and it will pass load of
parameters if into your methods um and then you need to do a subset of the things so you then don't need to modify
any of the generated code one thing we do find is not everyone's happy with the code that we've written um sometimes you

initialisms work if you have internal initialisms for things like internal
product names and stuff like that and you can also actually override all of the templates in the codebase
